questions.text: An infectious disease has its incubation period as 5-14 days, with its median incubation period being 10 days. The quarantine of contacts traveling to a new country should be done for: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 14 days


Quarantine is the process of separating and restricting the movement of healthy individuals who may have been exposed to an infectious disease, to prevent its spread. Quarantine is typically implemented for the maximum incubation period of the disease, which is the time between exposure to the infection and the onset of symptoms.

 

In this case, the maximum incubation period is 14 days. Therefore, quarantine should be conducted for 14 days to ensure that if symptoms develop, they will appear within this period, confirming the need for isolation and treatment.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Quarantine should be conducted for the maximum incubation period of the infectious disease to ensure that symptoms will manifest within that time, confirming whether a contact becomes a case.

Based on the national immunization schedule, which combination of vaccines would you recommend for this child's initial immunization? [AIIMS MAY 2018]

questions.text: The time gap between entry of organism in human body and its maximal infectivity is: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Generation time

 

Generation time is defined as the time interval between the entry of an infectious organism into the human body and the period when the individual reaches maximal infectivity. This concept is crucial in understanding the spread of infectious diseases, as it indicates when an infected person is most likely to transmit the infection to others.

 

Generation time helps public health professionals predict the spread of disease and is essential in planning control measures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incubation period: This option is incorrect. The incubation period is the time from exposure to the onset of first sign/symptom, not specifically related to the peak of infectivity.

 

Option B. Median IP: This option is incorrect. Median incubation period refers to the time by which 50% of cases exhibit symptoms, unrelated to infectivity.

 

Option C.  Serial IP (Serial Interval Period): This option is incorrect. The serial interval measures the gap between symptom onset in a primary case and a secondary case, not between entry of the organism and peak infectivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Generation time is the interval between the entry of an organism into the body and the point of maximal infectivity.

questions.text: Calculate the kappa statistics for the given dataset while comparing the IGRA and Mantoux test. [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 0.4

 

 

The kappa statistic is frequently used to test interrater reliability.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The kappa statistic measures the agreement between two tests beyond chance.
  • In this case, the kappa statistic is 0.4, indicating moderate agreement between the IGRA and Mantoux tests.

questions.text: Angular stomatitis and glossitis are associated with which vitamin deficiency?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Riboflavin

 

Explanation: 

 

Riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency is most characteristically associated with angular stomatitis, also known as cheilosis, which is inflammation of the corners of the mouth. Additionally, riboflavin deficiency can lead to atrophic glossitis, also referred to as geographic tongue. These oral manifestations are the hallmark signs of riboflavin deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency results in pellagra, which is characterized by the "4 D's": diarrhea, dermatitis (especially around the Casal's necklace), dementia, and death if left untreated. While pellagra can have significant consequences, it is not primarily associated with angular stomatitis and glossitis.

 

Option C. Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency can cause beriberi in populations consuming polished rice and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome in chronic alcoholics. Beriberi affects the nervous and cardiovascular systems, while Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome is characterized by neurological symptoms. However, thiamine deficiency is not directly linked to angular stomatitis and glossitis.

 

Option D. Cyanocobalamin (vitamin B12) deficiency is common in strict vegetarians and can lead to peripheral neuropathy, megaloblastic anemia, and subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord as a severe complication. Pernicious anemia may also occur as a result of vitamin B12 deficiency. While these conditions are serious, they are not specifically associated with angular stomatitis and glossitis.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Angular stomatitis (cheilosis) and atrophic glossitis (geographic tongue) are the most characteristic oral manifestations of riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency.

questions.text: As per WHO, the definition of blindness is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) <3/60.

 

The World Health Organization (WHO) defines blindness as having visual acuity of less than 3/60 in the better eye with the best possible correction. This means that a person who is blind cannot see at 3 meters what someone with normal vision can see at 60 meters. This definition is used globally to classify and diagnose blindness.

 

The same definition is used in the National Programme for Control of Blindness (NPCB) in India, ensuring consistency in how blindness is categorized both internationally and within the country.

 

Note –

 

  • In India, the current prevalence of blindness is 0.36%.
  • The most common cause of blindness is cataract (62%) >> refractive error (19.7%). 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blindness, as defined by the WHO, is visual acuity of less than 3/60 in the better eye with the best possible correction.

questions.text: Maternal deaths per 1,00,000 women in the reproductive age group is: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Maternal mortality rate

 

The maternal mortality rate refers to the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 women of reproductive age (usually between 15 and 49 years) in a given time period. This rate considers the entire population of women in the reproductive age group and not just those giving birth. It helps in assessing the risk associated with pregnancy and childbirth among all women in the reproductive age group.

 

PPH is the most common cause of Maternal mortality in India

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perinatal mortality rate: This rate measures the number of stillbirths and deaths in the first week of life per 1,000 total births. It does not specifically pertain to maternal deaths.

 

Option B. Maternal death rate: Although similar in terminology, this option is not used commonly and does not fit the precise definition provided for maternal mortality metrics.

 

Option D. Maternal mortality ratio: This ratio measures the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births in a given time period. It specifically relates to deaths due to complications during pregnancy, childbirth, or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy but does not include the entire reproductive age group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The maternal mortality rate measures the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 women in the reproductive age group, focusing on the general population of women of reproductive age rather than only those who have given birth.

questions.text: A biostatistics professor is teaching a group of medical students about the fundamentals of statistics. She mentions a branch that is specifically concerned with summarizing and presenting data in a meaningful way. Which of the following branches is she most likely referring to? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Descriptive statistics

 

Descriptive Statistics:

 

  • Data is summarised through the given observations; summarisation is done from a sample of population using parameters such as the mean or standard deviation.
  • Descriptive statistics is a way to organise, represent and describe a collection of data using tables, graphs, and summary measures

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Theoretical statistics: Focuses on the underlying mathematical theory and development of statistical methods, not on data summarization and presentation.

 

Option C. Analytical statistics: This term is less commonly used and does not represent a standard branch of statistics like descriptive or inferential statistics.

 

Option D. Inferential Statistics: Involves using data from a sample to make predictions or inferences about a larger population, including hypothesis testing and confidence intervals.

 

Additional Information

 

Applied Statistics:

 

  • Pure statistics focuses primarily on the numbers, maths, and problems themselves (theoretical)
  • Applied statistics on the other hand, can be thought of as “statistics-in-action” or using statistics with an eye toward real-world problems and what their solutions might be.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Descriptive statistics is dedicated to summarizing and presenting data in an easily understandable way, utilizing tables, graphs, and summary measures.

questions.text: Mental Health Gap Action (mhGAP) Program does not include: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) OCD

 

The Mental Health Gap Action Program (mhGAP) by the World Health Organization (WHO) is designed to scale up services for mental, neurological, and substance use disorders, particularly in low- and middle-income countries. The program focuses on priority conditions that are of high burden and can be managed effectively in primary care settings.

 

The mnemonic "MESSI DAD" can be used to remember the disorders included in the mhGAP program:

 

  • M: Mental disorders in children (Option A)
  • E: Epilepsy
  • S: Suicide
  • S: Schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders (Option B)
  • I: Illicit drug use disorders
  • D: Depression (Option D)
  • A: Alcohol-related disorders
  • D: Dementia

 

Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) is not included in the list of target conditions under the mhGAP program, which is why it is the correct answer to this question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

OCD (Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder) is not included in the WHO's Mental Health Gap Action (mhGAP) program, which focuses on other high-burden mental health conditions.

questions.text: Which of these methods relies on behavioral sciences? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Management by objective

 

Management by objective (MBO) is a technique based on behavioral sciences. It was developed by Peter Drucker in the 1950s and emphasizes the importance of setting clear goals and objectives that are aligned with organizational goals, and then measuring progress towards achieving those objectives.

 

MBO is based on the idea that individuals are motivated by the achievement of goals and that they perform better when they know what is expected of them. The technique involves a participatory process where employees are involved in setting their own goals and objectives, which are then reviewed and evaluated by their managers. This approach is intended to improve communication and collaboration within organizations, and to help employees feel more engaged and motivated in their work.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decision making:  This can rely on both behavioral sciences and quantitative methods, but in the context of management and organizational processes, it often involves analytical and quantitative approaches.

 

Option B. Systems analysis:  This is a quantitative method used to understand and analyze complex systems and processes, often involving mathematical models and simulations.

 

Option C. Network analysis:  This is a quantitative method used to plan and control complex projects, involving techniques like PERT (Program Evaluation and Review Technique) and CPM (Critical Path Method).

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the most important assessment based on the treatment given to the patient and their clinical management in a health care facility? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Process

 

Evaluation of "process" can assess a health care facility based on the treatment given to the patient and their clinical management.

 

The process of evaluation involves several steps, such as

 

  • Determining what needs to be evaluated
  • Establishing standards and criteria
  • Planning the methodology
  • Gathering information
  • Analyzing the results
  • Taking action
  • Re-evaluating

 

There are three types of evaluation: structure evaluation, process evaluation, and outcome evaluation.

 

  1. Evaluation of "structure": This is evaluation of whether facilities, equipment, manpower and organization meet a standard accepted by experts as good.
  2. Evaluation of "process": The process of medical care includes the problems of recognition, diagnostic procedures, treatment and clinical management, care and prevention. The way in which the various activities of the programme is carried out is evaluated by comparing with a predetermined standard. An objective and systematic way of evaluating the physician (or nurse) performance is known as "Medical (or nursing) Audit"
  3. Evaluation of "outcome": This is concerned with the end results, that is, whether persons using health services experience measurable benefits such as improved survival or reduced disability. The traditional outcome components are the "5 Ds" of ill-health, viz. disease, discomfort, dissatisfaction, disability and death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Outcome: Focuses on the end results of healthcare, such as improved health status and reduced disease and disability.

 

  • Not Correct: It measures the results of care, not the processes used to deliver it.

 

Option C. Structure: Examines the physical and organizational infrastructure, like facilities, equipment, and staffing.

 

  • Not Correct: It evaluates resources and infrastructure, not the actual delivery of care.

 

Option D. Input: Assesses resources required for healthcare, such as funding, manpower, and materials.

 

  • Not Correct: It looks at the resources used, not how care is delivered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "process" evaluation is the most relevant assessment for determining the quality of treatment and clinical management provided to patients in a healthcare facility. It focuses on the procedures and methods used in patient care, ensuring adherence to established standards and guidelines.

choices.text: Only CD4 contributed to graft rejection significantly
Only CD8 contributed to graft rejection significantly
Both CD4 and CD8 protected against graft rejection significantly
Both CD4 and CD8 contributed to graft rejection significantly

questions.text: For the given Kaplan-Meier curve on the role of T-cells in the allograft rejection process, true statement is: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Both CD4 and CD8 contributed to graft rejection significantly

 

The Kaplan-Meier curve presented in this question shows the survival rates of grafts in mice after they were treated with monoclonal antibodies designed to deplete specific T-cells (CD4 and CD8). The survival curves illustrate how the presence or absence of these T-cells affects graft rejection.

 

  • Anti-CD8 Group (Pink Line): The curve for mice treated with anti-CD8 antibodies (which deplete CD8 T-cells) shows a survival rate very similar to the control group. This indicates that the removal of CD8 T-cells alone does not significantly affect graft survival.
  • Anti-CD4 Group (Blue Line): The curve for the anti-CD4 group shows an extended graft survival compared to the control and anti-CD8 groups. This indicates that CD4 T-cells play a more significant role in graft rejection than CD8 T-cells alone. Removal of CD4 prolongs survival from 15 to 30 days.
  • Anti-CD4 + Anti-CD8 Group (Green Line): The green curve represents mice treated with both anti-CD4 and anti-CD8 antibodies. This group shows the longest survival of grafts, extending up to 60 days. The combination of depleting both CD4 and CD8 T-cells significantly delays graft rejection, demonstrating that both types of T-cells are involved in the rejection process.

 

The conclusion drawn from this curve is that both CD4 and CD8 T-cells contribute to graft rejection, and their combined effect is more pronounced than the effect of either cell type alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Both CD4 and CD8 T-cells are crucial contributors to the allograft rejection process, and their combined depletion significantly prolongs graft survival.

questions.text: During a complex surgical procedure in an operating theatre (OT) of a tertiary care hospital, a significant amount of blood is spilled onto the floor. To ensure proper disinfection of the spilled blood and mitigate risks associated with blood-borne pathogens, which compound should be used for effective cleaning? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Chlorine compound

 

Sodium hypochlorite, a chlorine compound, is the best disinfectant for cleaning blood spills. It effectively neutralizes blood-borne pathogens, ensuring a sterile environment in the OT. For a blood spill, a 1% hypochlorite solution should be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenolic compound: Not as effective for blood spills.

 

Option B. Alcoholic compound: Ineffective for large blood spills as it may not fully neutralize pathogens.

 

Option C. Quaternary ammonium compounds: Less effective against blood-borne pathogens in spills.

 

Educational Objective:


For disinfecting blood spills, a 1% sodium hypochlorite solution is the most effective compound to ensure proper disinfection and safety.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the clinic for a routine check-up. During the social history taking, she mentions that she has started engaging in certain behaviors and rituals that align with her new community after recently moving to a different country. What is the term for this type of behavior acquisition? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Socialization

 

Explanation:

 

  • Learning and try to adapt to new community. This is known as Socialization
  • Socialization is the process by which individuals learn and adopt the norms, values, and behaviors appropriate to their society. 
  • Socialization is key in helping individuals function as members of their society, and it involves learning the language, norms, and rituals of the community.
  • This term directly applies to the scenario described, as the woman is adopting behaviors that align with her new community.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Custom: This term refers to a traditional and widely accepted way of behaving or doing something that is specific to a particular society, place, or time. Customs are the established patterns of behavior that can be objectively verified within a particular social setting

 

Option B. Culture: Is the learned behavior which is socially acquired. Culture is a broader term that includes knowledge, belief systems, art, morals, laws, and any other capabilities and habits acquired by individuals as members of society.

 

Option D. Mores: These are the moral norms, manners, or customs that are considered important for the welfare of a community and are enforced by social disapproval or formal sanctions if violated. Mores are a subset of social norms that include strong moral connotations and are seen as foundational to societal welfare.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

"Socialization" best captures the process the woman is undergoing as she adopts the practices of her new community.

questions.text: According to IMNCI, a 6-month-old child is said to have pneumonia if the child has fast breathing with a respiratory rate more than: [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 50

 

In the Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness (IMNCI) guidelines, fast breathing is a key indicator for diagnosing pneumonia in children. The breathing rate cutoffs are age-specific:

 

  • For children less than 2 months old: > 60 breaths per minute.
  • For children aged 2 to 12 months: > 50 breaths per minute.
  • For children aged 12 to 60 months: > 40 breaths per minute.

 

Therefore, for a 6-month-old child, a respiratory rate greater than 50 breaths per minute is considered indicative of pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to IMNCI, a 6-month-old child is considered to have pneumonia if the respiratory rate is more than 50 breaths per minute.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man from a rural area presents with acute diarrhea, knee swelling, and abdominal distension after his family began using mustard oil for cooking. Which condition is most likely causing these symptoms? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Epidemic dropsy

 

Epidemic dropsy is caused by the adulteration of mustard oil with argemone oil, which contains the toxic compound sanguinarine. This toxin interferes with metabolic processes, leading to symptoms like acute diarrhea, bilateral swelling (edema), abdominal distension, and in severe cases, cardiac complications and glaucoma. The presence of these symptoms following the introduction of a new cooking oil strongly suggests epidemic dropsy.

 

Other characteristics of Epidemic Dropsy:

 

  • Epidemic dropsy may occur in all ages except breast – fed infants
  • The mortality of epidemic dropsy varies from 5-50%
  • Edema in epidemic dropsy occurs due to proteinuria (specifically loss of albumin).
  • Argemone oil may be detected by following tests:
    • Nitric acid test
    • Paper chromatography test: Most sensitive test

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endemic ascites: Caused due to toxin Pyrrolizidine in millets when adulterated with Crotolaria seeds. It is hepatotoxic.

 

Option C. Aflatoxicosis: Caused by Aflatoxin secreted by Aspergillus Flavus affecting the stored food items like grains, nuts and rice. It leads to Cirrhosis

 

Option D. Lathyrism: Caused by Beta Oxalyl Amino Alanine in Khesari Dal. It leads to neurological features like inability to walk, clumsy gait, jerky steps etc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Food Adulteration Diseases

questions.text: In a standard normal distribution, what percentage of data values fall within one standard deviation of the mean? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 68%

 

In a standard normal distribution, the data is symmetrically distributed around the mean, forming a bell-shaped curve known as the Gaussian distribution. This distribution is characterized by the following properties:

 

  • The mean, median, and mode of the distribution are equal and located at the center of the curve.
  • The curve is bilaterally symmetrical, meaning if a perpendicular line is drawn from the top of the curve, it divides the graph into two equal halves.

 

One of the key features of a standard normal distribution is that it follows the empirical rule, which states:

 

 

Therefore, the percentage of data values that fall within one standard deviation of the mean in a standard normal distribution is approximately 68%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a standard normal distribution, 68% of the data values fall within one standard deviation of the mean.

questions.text: Where chemical waste can be disposed? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Yellow

 

Chemical waste is disposed of in yellow-colored containers.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: You are a researcher aiming to compile and analyze data from various independent studies to enhance the precision of treatment effect estimates for a specific medical condition. Which of the following methodologies is most appropriate for achieving this objective? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Meta-analysis

 

Preference of epidemiological studies for establishing causality:

 

  • 1st preference: Meta-analysis
  • 2nd preference: Randomised controlled trials (RCTs)
  • 3rd preference: Retrospective (Non-concurrent/ Historical) cohort study
  • 4th preference: Prospective cohort study (Concurrent cohort study)
  • 5th preference: Case control study
  • 6th preference: Cross-sectional study
  • 7th preference: Ecological study

 

Meta-analysis

 

  • An objective, systematic review that employs statistical methods to combine and summarize the results of several studies. 
  • A quantitative synthesis of all unbiased evidence, meant for summarizing large volume of data, establishing and determining the magnitude of an effect, and to increase power and precision of studies

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cohort study: Observational study design, not suitable for synthesizing data from multiple studies.

 

Option B. Systematic review: Provides a qualitative synthesis of evidence but does not statistically combine results.

 

Option D. RCT (Randomized Controlled Trial): Primary study design, not a method for combining results from multiple studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Meta-analysis is the most effective quantitative approach for synthesizing data from multiple research studies to derive a more precise estimate of the treatment effect.
  • Preference of epidemiological studies for establishing causality - 1st preference is - Meta-analysis

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents to your clinic with a concern about a hypopigmented patch on her forearm. She has noticed reduced sensation over the patch. During the physical examination, you also notice thickening of some peripheral nerves. Which of the following combinations of criteria would be appropriate for diagnosing Leprosy in suspected cases? [INICET NOV 2022]

 

  1. Hypopigmented skin lesions with sensory deficit
  2. Peripheral nerve thickening with sensory loss and muscle weakening
  3. Family history of leprosy
  4. Slit skin smears
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4

 

To diagnose Leprosy, at least one of the following cardinal signs must be present:

 

1. Hypopigmented or reddish skin lesions with definite sensory deficit: This is a primary indicator of Leprosy. The presence of sensory deficits in these lesions points to the nerve involvement characteristic of the disease.

 

2. Peripheral nerve involvement - thickening with sensory loss and muscle weakening/paralysis: Thickening of peripheral nerves, combined with sensory loss and muscle weakening or paralysis, is another key indicator of Leprosy. These clinical signs suggest the spread of the infection to peripheral nerves.

 

4. Demonstration of M. leprae in lesions (Slit skin smears): This involves laboratory confirmation through slit skin smears showing the presence of Mycobacterium leprae. It is a definitive diagnostic method for Leprosy.

 

Other Options:

 

3. family history of leprosy is not considered one of the cardinal signs necessary for diagnosis. It is more relevant in understanding the epidemiological context rather than serving as a primary diagnostic criterion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At least one of the following cardinal signs must be present to diagnose Leprosy

 

  1. Hypopigmented or reddish skin lesions with definite sensory deficit
  2. Peripheral nerve involvement - thickening with sensory loss and muscle weakening/paralysis
  3. Demonstration of M. leprae in lesions (Slit skin smears)

questions.text: Dr. Sharma, the head of the pediatric department at a renowned medical college in Uttar Pradesh, is conducting a training session for new medical officers. As part of the session, he aims to ensure the officers are well-versed with the national health programs related to child health. He poses the question, "Under the Rashtriya Bal Swashthya Karyakram (RBSK) initiative, which of these diseases is not covered? [AIIMS MAY 2020]

  • While congenital cataract is explicitly mentioned as part of the initiative's coverage, congenital glaucoma is not typically listed among the prioritized conditions for screening under the RBSK.
  • This omission might be due to the relative rarity or specific screening requirements of congenital glaucoma compared to more commonly addressed conditions in public health programs.

 

Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK)

Targeted diseases:

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with no significant medical history, who has been using depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA) for contraception, presents to the clinic after missing her scheduled injection by 14 days. She denies any sexual activity since her last injection. Her last menstrual period was 10 weeks ago, and she has no signs of pregnancy. What is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient regarding contraception? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Give DMPA

 

Explanation:

 

  • As per the ministry of health and family welfare guidelines, ideally Inj DMPA (Antara) should be administered 3 monthly as shown in the table below:

 

Follow up of clients (coming on scheduled date for next injection i.e after 3 months

 

 

  • Defaulter: A defaulter is a client who does not return for the next injection on the scheduled date; but comes for it within the grace period i.e. 2 weeks earlier and upto 4 weeks later from the scheduled date).

 

 

Drop out: A dropout is a MPAclient who comes for the next injection after the grace period of 4 weeks is over and more than 4 months have passed since she took her last injection

 

 

In the scenario mentioned above, the patient is a DEFAULTER and hence the Inj should be administered as she falls within the grace period

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. UPT before DMPA: This would be appropriate if the patient was a drop-out, i.e. if she had presented > 4 weeks of the date that she had to come on. 

 

Option C. Give DMPA with 7 days of barrier: This approach would be recommended if the injection was delayed beyond 4 weeks. 

 

Option D. Wait till next period: This unnecessarily delays contraceptive protection and is not recommended.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When a patient misses her scheduled DMPA injection by up to 30 days, the most appropriate recommendation is to administer DMPA directly without pregnancy testing. 

  • This is because Inj DMPA is known to cause a delayed return to fertlity. 

  • This ensures continuous contraceptive protection while following evidence-based guidelines that balance safety with practical clinical considerations.

questions.text: A pediatrician reviews medical records of children aged 6-10 years to determine if there's a higher history of MMR vaccination in children with autism compared to those without. What type of observational study design is this? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Case control study

 

The above given example is that of a case control study, wherein two groups of children are selected- one group with autism and another one without autism. From these two groups, we want to find out the association between the history of MMR vaccination (cause) and autism (effect) by moving in a retrospective/backward direction. In case control study designs, the strength of association is found out by calculating the odds ratio.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cohort study: Follows a group over time to see how exposures affect outcomes.

 

Option C. Cross sectional study: Observes a population at a single point in time to find prevalence of an outcome or characteristic.

 

Option D. Ecological study: Examines population-level data rather than individual-level data.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A case control study compares groups with and without a condition to identify past exposures or risk factors.

questions.text: While working at a rural health sub-centre, you and a medical intern are analyzing annual infant registration metrics. The intern inquires about the expected annual infant registration rate when a health worker is actively on duty at the sub center. What is the best representation of this rate? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 150

 

Each year, a total of 150 infants should be enrolled at a sub-centre.

 

Annual infant population = Total population × % infants in population or expected birth rate

 

The infant population percentage, or the anticipated birth rate, ought to be derived from local data. In cases where a specific local percentage is not accessible, it is approximated at 3% of the overall population.

 

Total population in a sub centre = 5000.

 

Here, annual infant population = 5000 × 3/100 = 150

 

Total population catered by a Sub centre = 5000

 

Crude birth rate (CBR) India = 19 per 1000 Mid-year population (SRS 2016)

 

So, estimated number of births in a year = 19/1000 ×5000 = 95 births per year

 

  • Also, current Infant mortality rate (IMR) India = 28 per 1000 Live births
  • So, Expected number of infant deaths in a year in that population = 28/1000 × 95 = 2.7 deaths
  • So, total number of expected alive infants = 95 – 2.7 = 92 Infants approximately

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a rural health sub-centre, the expected annual infant registration rate effectively captures both the births and adjustments for infant mortality.
  • The number 150 serves as a practical target for ensuring all newborns are accounted for within the community health system.
  • This figure supports proactive health planning and resource allocation, emphasizing the importance of accurate and timely health data registration.

choices.text: FeSO4 + Vit C + Folate + Vit B12

questions.text: You work as a medical officer in a Primary Health Center (PHC). You are tasked with developing a strategy to address widespread anemia in the community. Considering the need for efficacy, safety, and ease of administration, which of the following options would you recommend for the prevention and treatment of anemia in this setting? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) FeSO4 + Vit C + Folate + Vit B12

 

  • Among the given options, FeSO4 + vitamin C + Folate + vitamin B12 is likely to be the best mass prophylaxis against anemia.
  • Vit C enhances the absorption of iron from the stomach by acting as a reducing substance.
  • Supplementing vitamin B12 can reduce incidence and prevalence of megaloblastic anemia as cost factor is not that significant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Iron (III) hydroxide polymaltose: It is not yet evident to be more efficacious than FeSO4

 

Option C. Ferrous fumarate: It is considered to be equally efficacious but vitamin C as an adjunct improves absorption.

 

Option D. Injection iron sucrose: Injection iron sucrose or any parenteral form is a first-line option. It is only indicated if the oral form is not tolerated or patient is not compliant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The comprehensive and cost-effective approach, including FeSO4 + Vitamin C + Folate + Vitamin B12, is preferable for the widespread prevention and treatment of anemia in a community setting, especially in a resource-limited Primary Health Center (PHC).

questions.text: During a global health conference, you're in a discussion with fellow epidemiologists about the changing patterns of disease occurrence over the years. The conversation shifts towards the steady rise in non-communicable diseases over a considerable time span. One of your colleagues quizzes the group on the terminology for such a trend. Which term best describes this pattern of increasing prevalence over extended periods? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Secular 

 

  • This kind of pattern can be explained by secular trend.
  • Secular Trends (Long Term Fluctuations): Implies changes in occurrence of a disease (progressive increase or decrease) over a long period of time, generally several years or decades.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seasonal: Seasonal trends (Periodic fluctuations) is seasonal variation/fluctuation in occurrence of a disease. Examples: Measles (early spring), upper respiratory infection (winters), gastrointestinal infection (summer).

 

Option B. Cyclical: Cyclic trend (Periodic fluctuations) is occurrence of a disease in cycles spread over short periods of time, which may be days, weeks, months or years. Examples: Measles (every 2-3 years), Rubella (every 6-9 years), Influenza pandemics (every 10-15 years).

 

Option C. Periodic: Periodic fluctuations include both Seasonal and cyclical trends.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Secular trends describe long-term changes in disease occurrence over years or decades, distinct from seasonal or cyclical variations.

questions.text: You're mentoring a group of budding epidemiologists who are keen on understanding the nuances of different study designs. One of them is particularly interested in case-control studies. During your discussion, you decide to quiz them on aspects that are typically not inherent to case-control studies. Which of the given options would not usually be part of a case-control study? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Follow up 

 

  • Follow up is not a component of case-control studies.
  • These studies are retrospective and do not involve tracking subjects over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Matching: Process of selecting controls in a such a way that they are similar to cases (with regard to certain pertinent selected variables which may influence the outcome of disease, thereby distorting the results). It eliminates confounding.

 

Option C. Strength of association: In case-control studies, the strength of association is measured using the odds ratio (an estimate of relative risk).

 

Option D. Selection of study subjects: Essential in case-control studies, involving the selection of cases with the disease and controls without the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Case-control studies do not include follow-up of subjects but focus on matching, assessing the strength of association using odds ratios, and selecting cases and controls for analysis.

choices.text: Mean = median, not equal to mode
Mode = median, not equal to mean

questions.text: The image shows two data distribution curves from separate studies within the same population: one depicted with a red line and the other with a blue line. Given the graphical representation, which of the following correctly represents the relationship among the mean, median, and mode for the data presented? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mean = median, not equal to mode

 

Analyzing the two graphs, we observe different distribution patterns:

 

  • Red line (Study A): The distribution is unimodal and symmetrical, indicating that the mean, median, and mode are all equal.
  • Blue line (Study B): The distribution is bimodal, showing two distinct peaks. In a bimodal distribution, the mean and median are typically equal, but there are two modes, making the mode not equal to the mean or median.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a bimodal distribution, the mean and median can be equal, but the mode will not be equal to them, as there are two modes.

questions.text: Dr. Radhika, the district health officer, is evaluating the efficiency of a subcenter in a rural region of India. This subcenter services a population of 5,000 people, and it has been reported that the crude birth rate (CBR) in this region stands at 20 per 1,000 people. Dr. Radhika wants to ensure that every pregnant woman receives antenatal care (ANC) to promote healthy pregnancies and reduce complications. With the current CBR, how many ANC registrations should the village health nurse (VHN) expect to handle annually? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 60

 

Calculation 

 

A subcentre serves a population of 5000 in plains.

 

CBR given is 20.

 

Expected number of pregnancies can be calculated by: Birth rate x population of the area / 1000 = 20 × 5000/1000 = 100.

 

A correction factor of 10% is added to adjust for pregnancy wastage in the form of abortions or stillbirths.

 

Hence, total number of expected pregnancies = Expected number of pregnancies + 10% of the same = 100 + 10 = 110

 

 Since not all pregnancies are officially registered, an Auxiliary Nurse Midwife (ANM) is typically expected to have at least half of the anticipated pregnancies under her care registered at any point in time. Therefore, the count of Antenatal Care (ANC) registrations is calculated as 50% of the projected pregnancies.

 

Therefore, Total ANC registrations expected = total number of expected pregnancies/2 = 55

 

The closest answer is 60.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In assessing ANC needs based on CBR in a rural health setting, it's crucial to accurately apply demographic statistics to the actual population size.
  • Expectations should align with direct calculations unless specific adjustments are warranted by local conditions or policies.

choices.text: Caters to a population of 1-1.5 lakh

U-CHC (URBAN - COMMUNITY HEALTH CENTRE)

  • 75-100 bedded U-CHC facilities in metros
  • U-CHC may be set up as a satellite hospital for every 4-5 U-PHCs

 

Educational Objective:

Educational Objective:

 

Aim of active Immunisation with TT:

  • Ensure protective level of antitoxin ~ 0.01 IU/mL serum throughout life

questions.text: In a 10-year-old school child, which of the following vaccines is given as a part of the school immunization program? [NEET PG 2023]

Age Limits for Delayed Immunization in NIS, India

 

 

Other Options:

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with confusion, difficulty walking, and memory problems. His wife reports that he has been a heavy drinker for the past 20 years. On examination, he has a wide-based gait and horizontal nystagmus. Laboratory tests reveal macrocytic anemia. Which of the following is the most likely deficiency causing his symptoms? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thiamine

 

The patient’s symptoms of confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia (as indicated by nystagmus) along with a history of chronic alcohol use suggest Wernicke's encephalopathy, which is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. Chronic alcohol consumption impairs thiamine absorption and utilization, leading to neurological deficits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B12:  While vitamin B12 deficiency can cause neurological symptoms and macrocytic anemia, it typically presents with subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, which is characterized by different symptoms such as paresthesias, ataxia, and weakness, without the triad seen in Wernicke's encephalopathy.

 

Option C. Folate: Folate deficiency can also lead to macrocytic anemia, but it does not typically cause the neurological deficits seen in this patient. Folate deficiency is more often associated with megaloblastic anemia without the specific neurological presentation.

 

Option D. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency is associated with bone diseases such as rickets and osteomalacia. It does not cause the neurological symptoms observed in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic alcohol consumption can lead to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, resulting in Wernicke's encephalopathy. The classic triad of symptoms includes confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia. Early recognition and treatment with thiamine are crucial to prevent progression to Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

questions.text: What immunization coverage percentage is required by the WHO for the eradication of measles? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 96% 

 

  • The World Health Organization (WHO) stipulates that to achieve the complete elimination of measles, an immunization coverage of at least 96% among children under the age of 1 is necessary. 
  • This high percentage is critical because measles is highly contagious. Such a high coverage rate ensures herd immunity, significantly reducing the chances of measles transmission and protecting those who are not immune.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To eradicate measles, the WHO recommends an immunization coverage of 96% among children under the age of 1, emphasizing the need for near-universal coverage to achieve herd immunity and effectively control the disease.

questions.text: A young girl has been experiencing repeated instances of yeast infections and respiratory virus infections since she was only 3 months old. Given her immune system's condition, which of the listed vaccines should not be administered to her? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Measles/MMR

 

Based on the information provided, the girl child has a history of recurrent yeast infections and respiratory virus infections since she was 3 months old. This suggests that she may have an underlying immunodeficiency.

 

In this scenario, the measles/MMR vaccine would be contraindicated due to the risk of causing a severe infection in an immunocompromised individual.

 

CONTRAINDICATIONS OF LIVE VACCINES –

 

  • Immunodeficient individuals (Symptomatic HIV infection) except BCG vaccine
  • Immunosuppressed individuals (patient with leukemia or patients on antimetabolites, steroids or radiation)
  • Pregnancy (except Yellow fever)

 

Additional Information

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Killed IPV (Inactivated Polio Vaccine): Safe for immunocompromised individuals as it does not contain live virus.

 

Option C. DPT (Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus): Safe for immunocompromised individuals as it is not a live vaccine.

 

Option D. TT/Td (Tetanus Toxoid/Tetanus and Diphtheria): Safe for immunocompromised individuals as it is not a live vaccine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Live vaccines like Measles/MMR should not be administered to immunocompromised individuals due to the risk of severe infection. Instead, inactivated or subunit vaccines, which do not contain live pathogens, should be used.

questions.text: You are posted as a medical officer in a rural Primary Health Centre (PHC) for your rural internship. As part of your duties, you are required to oversee and understand the roles and responsibilities of ASHA working in your region. Which of the following tasks is NOT traditionally a responsibility of the ASHA worker? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Malaria slide preparation

 

  • ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist) workers play a crucial role in community health, especially in rural areas of India.
  • Their responsibilities are extensive but focused primarily on preventive and promotive healthcare. But not the malaria slides preparation.
  • Preparation of malaria slides is the responsibility of health worker male.

 

Other 3 options are ASHA responsibilities

 

Educational Objective:

 

Responsibilities of ASHA:

 

  • Create awareness on health and its social determinants and mobilize the community towards local health planning and increased utilization and accountability of the existing health services
  • Promote good health practices and provide a minimum package of curative care as appropriate and feasible and make timely referrals
  • Provide information on determinants of health, on existing health services and the need for timely utilization of services
  • Counsel women on aspects of reproductive and child health
  • Mobilize the community and facilitate them in accessing health and health related services provided by the government
  • Act as a depot holder for essential provisions like ORS, IFA tablets, chloroquine, disposable delivery kits, oral pills & condoms
  • Provide primary medical care and act as DOTS provider
  • Help develop a comprehensive village health plan
  • Arrange escort/accompany pregnant women and children requiring treatment/ admission to nearest health facility
  • Be a part of JSY (Janani Suraksha Yojana) and help reduce MMR

 

Additional Information

 

Proposed population norm: 2 ASHA worker per 1000 population

 

ASHA is expected to act as,

 

  • Interface between: Community and Health care system
  • Bridge between: ANM and village
  • Accountable to: Panchayat

 

Selection criteria of ASHA:

 

  • Woman resident of local community
  • Preferably 25 – 45 years age
  • Literate with formal education up to 10th class (Relaxable for Tribal areas)

 

Indicators for Monitoring and Evaluation of ASHA’s Work

 

  • Process indicators:
    • No. of ASHAs selected
    • No. of ASHAs trained
    • % ASHAs attending review meeting after 1 year
  • Outcome indicators:
    • % newborns weighed and families counseled
    • % deliveries with skilled assistance
    • % institutional deliveries
    • % JSY claims made to ASHA
    • Completed immunized 12-23 months age group
    • % unmet need in BPL
    • % fever cases received chloroquine within 1 weeks in endemic area
  • Impact indicators:
    • Infant mortality rate (IMR)
    • Child malnutrition rates
    • No. of cases of TB/Leprosy detected as compared to last year.

choices.text: COV of DBP is more than Vitamin D
COV of Vitamin D is more than DBP
Both DBP and Vitamin D have equal variability
It cannot be ascertained from information provided

questions.text: During your clinical rotations, you are reviewing data from an experiment that examined the correlation between Vitamin D levels and diastolic blood pressure (DBP). The experiment aimed to ascertain the variability within two distinct sample sets. Based on the findings, the average DBP was noted to be 110, with an associated standard deviation of 11. Similarly, the mean Vitamin D level was observed to be 18, with a standard deviation of 3. With reference to the coefficient of variation (COV), which statement accurately represents the collected data? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) COV of Vitamin D is more than DBP

 

Coefficient of Variation (COV)

 

  • Is a measure used to compare relative variability
  • Is a unit-free measure to compare dispersion of one variable with another
  • Is SD expressed as percentage of mean

 

 

Calculation -

 

COV of DBP = 11/110 = 0.1

 

COV of Vitamin D = 3/18 = 0.166

 

Hence, COV of Vitamin D is more than DBP

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The coefficient of variation provides a useful comparison of variability across different datasets.
  • In this case, the higher COV for Vitamin D indicates a greater relative variation compared to DBP, highlighting important considerations for researchers analyzing the impacts or associations involving these variables.

questions.text: A 45-year-old urban health administrator is planning to set up a new Primary Health Centre (PHC) in an underserved urban area to cater to the healthcare needs of the local population. She is familiarizing herself with the human resource guidelines for urban PHCs. She understands that it is crucial to have the right number of staff for optimal functioning. Among the following staff requirements, she reviewed, which does NOT correctly represent the standard guidelines for staffing at an urban PHC? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 2 Staff nurses

 

According to the IPHS 2022 Guidelines for urban PHCs, the recommended staffing includes only 1 staff nurse, not 2 as listed in option D. Ensuring adherence to these guidelines is crucial for the optimal setup and functioning of the PHC.

 

Other 3 options are correct as per guidelines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urban - Primary Health Centre is designed to consist: (IPHS 2022 Guidelines)

 

  • 2 Doctors
  • 1 Staff nurse
  • 1 Pharmacist
  • 1 Lab technician
  • 1 Lady health visitor
  • 5 ANM
  • 1 Public Health Manager

 

U-PHC (Urban - Primary Health Centre):

 

  1. 1 per 50,000 population (near or within a slum)
  2. OPD (consultation), basic lab diagnosis, drug/ contraceptive dispensing and delivery of RCH services, as well as preventive and promotive aspects of all diseases

questions.text: During your rural internship, you are tasked with overseeing vaccine distribution to Community Health Centres (CHCs) and Primary Health Centres (PHCs). Due to the tropical climate and frequent power outages at your posting area, ensuring the vaccines' integrity is crucial. Which of the following tests would you employ to check if the vaccines have incurred any freeze damage due to temperature fluctuations? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Shake test

 

  • Utility: Used to check if Freeze sensitive vaccines have been damaged by exposure to freezing temperatures below 0 degrees C; After the test the previously Frozen vaccine shows flakes. Shake Test is used to assess the freeze damage to Aluminium based freeze sensitive vaccines such as DPT, TT, Td etc. 
  • Method of Shake test:
    • Test Vial: Vial which is suspected to have been frozen 
    • Frozen control vial: Take a similar (as Test vial) vaccine vial with same manufacturer, batch number, antigen(s), Label it properly. Freeze it overnight at -20 degrees C, then let it haw (Do not heat)
    • Hold the Test vial and Control vials between thumb and forefinger and shake them vigorously (10-15 seconds)
    • Place both vials on even flat surface for 30 minutes observation, compare the sedimentation rates (SR). If the sediments in the suspect vial settle more slowly, the suspect vaccine may be used.
  • Interpretation:
    • If SR in Test vial < Control vial: Vaccine had not been damaged
    • If SR in Test vial > Control vial: Vaccine had been damaged,

 

Do not use and Inform the supervisors

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Schick test: This is a skin test for susceptibility to diphtheria.

 

Option C. Habel test: This is used to measure the potency of rabies vaccines.

 

Option D. Tine test: This is a skin test for tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Shake Test currently applies to freeze sensitive vaccines which are:

 

  • DPT-Hep B-Hib
  • TT
  • PCV13
  • Hepatitis B
  • HPV

questions.text: MC direct cause of Maternal mortality is? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Post partum haemorrhage

 

Maternal mortality refers to the death of a mother during pregnancy, labor, delivery, or within 42 days after delivery.

 

The causes of maternal mortality can be categorized into direct and indirect causes.

 

Among the direct causes, post-partum hemorrhage (PPH) is the most common cause of maternal mortality in India. Other direct causes are obstructed labor and sepsis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anemia: Incorrect. As Anemia is the most common indirect cause of maternal mortality in India.

 

Option C. Obstructed labor: Incorrect. Although obstructed labor is a direct cause of maternal mortality, it is not as common as post-partum hemorrhage in India.

 

Option D. Sepsis: Incorrect. Sepsis is another direct cause of maternal mortality, but it is not as prevalent as post-partum hemorrhage in India.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-partum hemorrhage is the most common direct cause and anemia is the MC indirect cause of the maternal mortality in India, and PPH is also the overall leading cause of maternal deaths in the country.

 

India MMR (SRS 2023) – 97 per 1 lakh live births

choices.text: Years lost due to premature death
Years lost to poor quality of life

questions.text: The years of potential life lost could be attributed to? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Years lost due to premature death

 

Years of Potential Life Lost (YPLL)

 

Definition: YPLL is based on Years of life lost through premature death

 

Importance:

 

  • YPLL occurs before the age to which a dying person could have expected to survive
  • YPLL is a type of mortality indicator

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Years lost to morbidity refers to the time spent living with a disease or disability, which is not directly related to the concept of years of potential life lost.

 

Option C. Years lost to disability is a component of disability-adjusted life years (DALY). DALY Is BEST measure of burden of disease in a defined population and the effectiveness of interventions.

 

DALY = YLL (Years of lost life) + YLD (Years lost to disability)

 

Option D. life would account into QALY (Quality Adjusted Life Years)

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Years of Potential Life Lost (YPLL) is a measure that quantifies the impact of premature death on a population by calculating the number of years not lived by individuals who die before reaching a specified age. It highlights the significance of early mortality and its impact on society.

 In a developed country, leading causes of death are:

 

  1. Accident injury
  2. Congenital anomaly
  3. Neoplasms
  4. Influenza
  5. Pneumonia

questions.text: 6 x 6 x 6 Strategy under Anemia Mukt Bharat does not include: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6 Ministries

 

Explanation:

 

The Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) program aims to reduce the prevalence of anemia by 3 percentage points per year from 2018 to 2022. The program is implemented using the 6 x 6 x 6 strategy, which includes:

 

 

The strategy does not include 6 Ministries as one of its components.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 6 Beneficiaries: Children below 5 years, children aged 5-9 years, adolescents aged 10-19 years, women of reproductive age (20-49 years), pregnant women, and lactating women.

 

Option B. 6 Interventions: This includes iron and folic acid supplementation, deworming, intensified year-round behavior change communication (BCC), testing and treatment of anemia using digital methods and point of care treatment, mandatory provision of iron and folic acid fortified foods in government-funded health programs, and addressing non-nutritional causes of anemia in endemic pockets with special focus on malaria, hemoglobinopathies, and fluorosis.
