choices.text: Both the treatments are equally effective
Neither of the treatments is effective
The new treatment is more effective than the usual treatment
The information given is not adequate to compare the efficacy of the treatments

questions.text: In a well-designed cancer study, comparable rates of remission were achieved for both a new treatment (33.2%) and the conventional treatment (32.2%). The corresponding p-value was recorded as 0.04. Which of the following statements is true regarding the study? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) The new treatment is more effective than the usual treatment 

 

  • A p-value of 0.04 (< 0.05) indicates that the results are statistically significant and there is evidence to suggest that the new treatment is more effective than the usual treatment. 
  • Although the difference in remission rates is small, it is still statistically significant, which means that the new treatment may have some clinical benefits compared to the usual treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Both the treatments are equally effective: This statement is misleading because, although the remission rates are close, the statistical analysis (p-value < 0.05) indicates a significant difference, favoring the new treatment.

 

Option B. Neither of the treatments is effective: This option is incorrect as the statement about effectiveness cannot be deduced solely from the remission rates and p-value provided; effectiveness also depends on other factors such as comparison with control groups or historical data which are not mentioned here.

 

Option D. The information given is not adequate to compare the efficacy of the treatments: While more information about the study design and other factors could be beneficial, the p-value provided is adequate under standard scientific criteria to make a preliminary comparison regarding the efficacy of the treatments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Even small differences in treatment outcomes can be statistically significant. A p-value of less than 0.05, as seen in this study, typically supports the conclusion that the new treatment offers a measurable improvement over the conventional treatment in terms of remission rates.

questions.text: A 32-year-old public health researcher is analyzing maternal health data. She mentions a metric that represents the number of maternal deaths for every 100,000 live births in a specific year. Which term best describes this metric? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Maternal Mortality Ratio

 

Maternal mortality Ratio (MMR): Maternal deaths expressed as per 100,000 live births where a ‘maternal death’ is defined as ‘death of a women while pregnant of during delivery or within 42 days (6 weeks) of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of duration or site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

 

  • Maternal deaths expressed as per 100,000 live births (earlier it was expressed per 1000 live births but that yielded fractions like 4.08 maternal deaths per 1000 LB; so, denominator was extrapolated to 100,000 to make MMR value more sensible)
  • MMR is a ratio

 

 

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

 

MMR World: 216 per 100,000 live births; Causes of MMR (globally):

 

  • Hemorrhage (25%)
  • Indirect causes (20%)
  • Infection (15%)
  • Unsafe abortion (13%)
  • Eclampsia (12%)
  • Obstructed labour (8%)

 

MMR India: 97 per 100,000 live births [2023]; Causes of MMR (India) [SRS 2023]:

 

  • Hemorrhage (38%)
  • Other conditions (34%)
  • Sepsis (11%)
  • Abortion (8%)
  • Obstructed labour (5%)
  • Hypertensive disorders (5%)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maternal mortality rate (MM Rate): Dividing the average annual number of maternal deaths in a population by the average number of women of reproductive age (typically those aged 15 to 49 years) who are alive during the observation period. 

MM Rate reflects not only the risk of maternal death per pregnancy or per birth, but also the level of fertility in a population

 

Option C. Infant Mortality Rate (IMR): The IMR measures the number of deaths of infants under one-year-old per 1,000 live births in a given year.

 

Option D. Perinatal Mortality Rate: This measures the number of stillbirths and deaths in the first week of life per 1,000 total births (live and still) in a given year.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is a critical metric representing the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births in a specific year and is vital for assessing the quality of obstetric care.

questions.text: Which disease is represented by the submerged portion of the iceberg in the iceberg model? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Influenza

 

The iceberg model represents diseases that have a visible portion (the tip) and a hidden portion (submerged part). The tip of the iceberg represents clinical cases that are easily diagnosed by healthcare providers, typically through visible symptoms. The submerged portion, which is much larger, represents the hidden cases, including asymptomatic, subclinical, latent, and pre-symptomatic individuals who still carry the disease but are not easily visible to healthcare providers.

 

Influenza exhibits the iceberg phenomenon because many individuals with the virus remain undiagnosed as they show mild or no symptoms. These hidden cases contribute significantly to the spread of the disease as these individuals do not seek medical attention and thus remain below the surface of clinical observation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tetanus: Tetanus does not exhibit the iceberg phenomenon because it does not have carriers or asymptomatic cases. The disease only manifests as clinical cases, which are visible to healthcare providers.

 

Option B. Measles: Measles does not have an iceberg phenomenon due to the absence of carriers and asymptomatic cases. It is typically a visible disease with noticeable symptoms once infection occurs.

 

Option C. Rubella: Similar to measles, rubella also does not have an iceberg phenomenon as it does not involve carriers or hidden cases. The infection is primarily identified through its clinical presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The iceberg phenomenon describes diseases with a significant proportion of hidden, asymptomatic, or subclinical cases, such as influenza, which contribute to disease transmission.

 

Remember – No carriers – No iceberg Phenomena – Measles, Rubella, Rabies, Tetanus and + Pertussis

choices.text: 2 doses of vaccine on Day 0 & 3
5 doses of vaccine with Immunoglobulin

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy, previously vaccinated against rabies a year ago, was bitten by his vaccinated family pet dog on the toe, resulting in a bleeding wound. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this child? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 2 doses of vaccine on Day 0 & 3

 

  • The patient should receive 2 doses of vaccine on days 0 & 3 as he has already received a prior course of post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) > 3 months ago.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a previously vaccinated individual bitten by a potentially rabid animal, the appropriate post-exposure prophylaxis is to administer 2 booster doses of the rabies vaccine on days 0 and 3.

choices.text: Give IV antibiotics and refer to higher centre
Oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home
No need of treatment only home remedies

questions.text: A pediatrician at a district hospital encounters an 18-month-old boy from a remote village with breathing difficulties, cough, cold, and fever for the past few days. The child is active, with a respiratory rate of 46 breaths per minute and no chest retractions. How should the pediatrician advise the parents? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home

 

  • Based on the provided clinical information, it is evident that the child is suffering from pneumonia.
  • The recommended treatment for pneumonia in children aged 2 months to 5 years involves administering oral amoxicillin along with home care.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is related to Navjat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Newborn

 

Navjat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (NSSK) is a program focused on the care of newborns or neonates, which refers to the first 7 days of life. The term "Navjat Shishu" itself means "early newborn" or "neonate."

 

NSSK is a training program designed for healthcare personnel at all levels, aiming to improve newborn care and resuscitation practices. It is a component of the Reproductive and Child Health (RCH) program under the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lactating women: NSSK does not specifically target lactating women, although proper newborn care and feeding practices are likely to be included in the training program.

 

Option B. Children: The Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) is a separate program that focuses on the health of children aged 0 to 18 years, not specifically newborns.

 

Option D. Pregnant women: While pregnant women are an important target group for various maternal health programs, like JSY, JSSK.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Navjat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (NSSK) is a training program for healthcare personnel at all levels, focusing on the care and resuscitation of newborns (neonates) in the first 7 days of life.

choices.text: If replacement feeding, the neonate should be tested for HIV, if negative, ART is not required.
In exclusive breastfeeding, give nevirapine for 6 months only when baby is positive
If replacement feeding, the neonate need not receive nevirapine if HIV negative
If exclusive replacement feeding, give nevirapine for 6 weeks, even if the baby is negative

questions.text: A pediatrician is providing counselling to a pregnant woman who is HIV positive about postnatal care for her soon-to-be-born child. Which of the following statements best captures the recommended management for an infant born to a mother with HIV regarding antiretroviral treatment (ART)? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) If exclusive replacement feeding, give nevirapine for 6 weeks, even if the baby is negative

 

The baby should be given prophylaxis irrespective of feeding status and HIV status at birth.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. If replacement feeding, the neonate should be tested for HIV, if negative, ART is not required: Incorrect. Prophylaxis with nevirapine should still be given for 6 weeks regardless of HIV status.

 

Option B. In exclusive breastfeeding, give nevirapine for 6 months only when baby is positive: Incorrect. Nevirapine is given as prophylaxis irrespective of the infant's HIV status.

 

Option C. If replacement feeding, the neonate need not receive nevirapine if HIV negative: Incorrect. Prophylaxis should still be provided for 6 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Infants of HIV-positive mothers on exclusive replacement feeding get 6-week nevirapine, regardless of their HIV status.

questions.text: A study on postpartum depression in mothers compares depression rates based on the gender of their newborns using the Edinburgh Depression Scale Score (EDSS). Which statistical method should be used to determine if there's a significant association between the newborn's gender and postpartum depression? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Chi square test

 

  • The Chi-square test serves the purpose of comparing qualitative data and involves the comparison of two groups with independent measurements.
  • Therefore, it is the most suitable test for this context

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Students t test: Used for comparing means of two independent groups; not suitable for categorical data.

 

Option B. Paired t test: Used for comparing means of related groups; not suitable for independent categorical data.

 

Option C. ANOVA: Used for comparing means of three or more groups; not suitable for categorical data with only two groups.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 33-year-old public health officer is assigned to lead a healthcare team aiming to address and manage endemic conditions in a remote village with limited healthcare access. As part of the initiative, there's a proposal to start a mass drug administration (MDA) program targeting common health concerns in the area. Which of the following conditions would NOT traditionally be managed through mass drug administration? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Vitamin A deficiency 

 

  • Mass Drug Administration (MDA) refers to providing a drug to an entire population without considering age and gender.
  • Vitamin A prophylaxis is exclusively administered as per the National Immunization Schedule (NIS) to children up to the age of 5.
  • This prophylactic treatment is not intended as a curative measure but rather as a preventive measure.
  • Treatment with vitamin A is reserved solely for children displaying symptoms of vitamin A deficiency, and such treatment is not widespread throughout the community.
  • As a result, it is not categorized as part of Mass Drug Administration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Worm infestation: Managed through MDA using albendazole or mebendazole to treat and prevent worm infestations in the population.

 

Option C. Scabies: Managed through MDA using ivermectin to treat and prevent scabies outbreaks in the community.

 

Option D. Filariasis: Managed through MDA using DEC (diethylcarbamazine) and albendazole to prevent and control filariasis in endemic areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vitamin A deficiency is managed through targeted prophylaxis in children rather than mass drug administration.
  • In contrast, MDA is carried out for conditions like scabies (using ivermectin), worm infestations (using albendazole), and filariasis (using DEC + albendazole).

choices.text: Diet should contain 400 kcal from carbohydrates
Diet should contain 800 kcal from fat

questions.text: What does the FDA say about a diet, high in fat intake? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Diet should contain total 1000 kcal

 

  • According to FDA, high fat diet is a diet having 50% of total caloric content of the meal and a high calorie diet is a diet containing total 1000 kcal.
  • This meal should derive approximately 150, 250, and 500-600 calories from protein, carbohydrate, and fat, respectively

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diet should contain 400 kcal from carbohydrates: Incorrect. While carbohydrates are a part of the diet, this specific statement does not match the FDA's guideline for a high-fat diet.

 

Option C. Diet should contain 800 kcal from fat: Incorrect. A high-fat diet typically derives around 500-600 kcal from fat, not 800 kcal.

 

Option D. Diet should contain 80% fats: Incorrect. A high-fat diet is defined by having around 50% of its caloric content from fats, not 80%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The FDA defines a high-fat diet as one that has around 50% of its total caloric intake from fats, and a high-calorie diet should contain a total of 1000 kcal.

choices.text: Type A PHC conducts < 20 deliveries per month
Provides maternal and child health care, family planning and MTP
Acts as a first referral unit
There is 1 PHC per 30000 population in plain areas

questions.text: A 32-year-old medical officer recently posted to a remote area to oversee the functioning of a Primary Health Centre (PHC) participates in workshops to familiarize herself with PHC mandates. Which of the following statements about PHCs is NOT accurate based on standard guidelines? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Acts as a first referral unit

 

Primary Health Centres (PHCs) are not designed to act as first referral units. The first referral level of healthcare in India is provided by Community Health Centres (CHCs).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type A PHC conducts < 20 deliveries per month: Correct as per guidelines.

 

Option B. Provides maternal and child health care, family planning, and MTP: Accurate description of PHC services.

 

Option D. There is 1 PHC per 30000 population in plain areas: Correct population norm for PHCs in plain areas.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Primary Health Centres (PHCs) serve as the first point of contact in the healthcare system, but the first referral unit is the Community Health Centre (CHC).

 

Additional Information

 

 

Levels of Primary Health Care System in India

 

  • Primary Level of Health Care:
    • Is ‘first level of contact between population and health care system’ in India.
    • Health services are delivered through:
      • Sub-centre
      • Primary Health Centre
  • Secondary Level of Health Care:
    • Is ‘First referral level of health care’ in India.
    • Health services are delivered through: Community Health Centre
  • Tertiary Level of Health Care:
    • Is ‘Second referral level of health care’ in India.
    • Health services are delivered through: Medical Colleges and Hospitals

choices.text: Fishing and fisheries beyond territorial waters

questions.text: Which item is included in the concurrent list of the Indian Constitution? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Adulteration of food

 

The concurrent list in the Indian Constitution includes subjects on which both the central and state governments can legislate. One of the items included in this list is the adulteration of food. The legislative framework in India is divided into three lists as per the seventh schedule of the Constitution:

 

  1. Union List: Contains subjects on which only the Parliament can make laws. This list includes 100 items, such as defense, foreign affairs, atomic energy, and others.
  2. State List: Contains subjects on which only the state legislatures can make laws. This list includes 61 items, such as police, public health, and agriculture.
  3. Concurrent List: Contains subjects on which both the Parliament and state legislatures can make laws. This list includes 52 items, such as criminal law, marriage and divorce, bankruptcy and insolvency, and the adulteration of food.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fishing and fisheries beyond territorial waters: This subject is included in the Union List, meaning that only the Parliament has the authority to legislate on this matter.

 

Option C. Regulating labor in mines: This subject is also included in the Union List, placing it under the legislative jurisdiction of the Parliament.

 

Option D. Public health and sanitation: This subject is included in the State List, meaning that only state governments have the exclusive authority to legislate on public health and sanitation matters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The adulteration of food is included in the Concurrent List of the Indian Constitution, allowing both the central and state governments to legislate on this issue. The Union List and State List contain subjects exclusive to the Parliament and state legislatures, respectively.

questions.text: What is the proper disposal method for a damaged vaccine vial according to biomedical waste management protocols? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Puncture proof blue bin 

 

Blue puncture proof container

 

Under BMW guidelines, Glassware and Metallic Body Implants are disposed in Cardboard boxes with blue colored marking/ puncture proof bins. These bins are specifically designed to safely handle glass and metallic body implants to prevent injury and ensure proper disposal.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Which of the provided options align with the depicted equivalence margin graph? [INICET MAY 2021]

 

 

  1. ‘A’ represents superiority of new treatment
  2. ‘I’ represents Inferiority of new treatment
  3. ‘E’ represents Non-inferior treatment
  4. ‘C’ is inconclusive
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 1, 2 and 3 

 

There are three types of comparators in Randomised Control Trials:

 

1. Superiority Trial – New drug is Better than old drug

 

2. Non-Inferiority Trial – New drug as good as old drug

 

3. Equivalence – New drug same as old drug

 

 

Other Option:

 

4. 'C' is inconclusive: This statement is incorrect as per the image. 'C' represents a superior treatment, as it falls well into the "new treatment better" region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In equivalence margin graphs for RCTs, 'A' can indicate a superior treatment, 'I' an inferior treatment, and 'E' a non-inferior treatment. 'C' does not represent an inconclusive result; it represents superiority.

choices.text: 1/3 of the total protein requirement + ½ of total energy requirement
2/3 of the total protein requirement + ½ of total energy requirement
½ of the total protein requirement + 1/3 of total energy requirement
½ of the total protein requirement + 2/3 of total energy requirement

questions.text: Dr. Anil, working as a nutritional consultant with the government of India, is reviewing the Mid-Day Meal (MDM) scheme, an initiative to enhance the nutritional intake among school-going children. He emphasizes that the nutritional component of the meals should not just be about filling stomachs but ensuring that children get adequate protein and energy to support their growth and learning. Given the constraints and the need to ensure minimal nutritional adequacy, what should the minimum supplementation be in the Mid-Day Meal to support the children's needs? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) ½ of the total protein requirement + 1/3 of total energy requirement

 

  • The meal should supplement 1/3 of the total energy requirement and 1/2 of the total protein requirement.
  • Mid-day meal programme (MDMP): Also known as ‘School Lunch Programme’, it has been in operation since 1961.
  • The major objective of MDMP: To attract more children for admission to schools and retain them so that literacy improvement of children could be brought about.
  • The meal is a supplement and not a substitute to the home diet
  • The meal should supply 1/3 of the total energy requirement and 1/2 of the total protein requirement
  • MDMP is being operationalised under the Ministry of Human Resource & Development 
  • National Institute of Nutrition, Hyderabad is of the view that minimum number of feeding days in year be 250 to have the desired impact on children

 

Mid-day meal scheme (MDMS) (National Programme of Nutritional Support to Primary Education):

 

  • Launched in 1995
  • Main objective: Universalisation of primary education by increasing enrolment, retention and attendance and simultaneously impacting on nutrition of students in primary classes
  • The mid-day meal should supply 1/3 of the total energy requirement and 1/2 of the total protein requirement
  • A model menu for mid-day school meal

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Principles for formulating mid-day meals:

 

  • Meal should be a supplement only not a substitute for home diet
  • Meal should provide 1/3 calories and 1/2 proteins
  • Meal cost should be low
  • Complicated cooking process must not be involved
  • Use locally available foods
  • Keep changing menu frequently

 

Mid-Day Meal Scheme is now renamed as PM POSHAN or Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man from Mumbai presents to a clinic with fatigue and weakness. His family has a history of chronic diseases, but he himself has been asymptomatic until recently. The physician explains the different stages of disease progression and the interventions required. Which of the following best matches the stages with their relevant descriptions? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 1-d, 2-b, 3-a, 4-c

 

  • Natural history of disease refers to the progression of a disease in an individual over time, in the absence of treatment. It has two phases, a period of pre-pathogenesis and a period of pathogenesis.

 

 

  • The period of pre-pathogenesis is before the onset of disease in humans.
  • An interaction between the agent, host and the environment occurs in this phase before the pathogenesis.
  • It starts with appropriate exposure to or accumulation of factors sufficient for the disease process to begin in a susceptible host.
  • The exposure is a microorganism in an infectious disease. For lung cancer, it is any factor that initiates the process, such as asbestos fibres or components in tobacco smoke.
  • Primary prevention (health promotion and specific protection) is applicable in this period.
  • The period of pathogenesis starts after the disease process has been triggered and pathological changes occur without the individual being aware of it.
  • It begins with the entry of the organism till recovery, death, or disability.
  • The subclinical or asymptomatic period between exposure and onset of symptoms is called the incubation period for infectious diseases, and the latency period for chronic diseases.
  • The onset of clinical symptoms is the beginning of the clinical stage of the disease.
  • Secondary (halting of the disease process) and tertiary prevention (measures to limit disability) are applicable in this period.
  • Rehabilitation has been defined as the use of medical, social, educational, and vocational measures for training the individual to the highest possible level of functional ability.
  • It is a part of tertiary prevention like providing callipers for walking patients and arranging schooling after being affected by polio.

 

Educational Objective:
